body: BTW, is build from Makefile supported or should we use cmake instead?

Looks like the problem is here: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/templates/Makefile.template#L1337

The `settings.core_version.major` is used for symlinks, this is correct for C but not C++. (Why are the versions different?).

For some unknown reason, I got the correct symlinks with `make install` on debian, but not on fedora.
```
[fedora@fedora helloworld]$ ls -l /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.*
-rwxr-xr-x. 1 root root 1809138 Jun 12 23:54 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.a
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root      18 Jun 12 23:54 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so -> libgrpc++.so.1.3.2
-rwxr-xr-x. 1 root root  737272 Jun 12 23:54 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so.1.3.2
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root      18 Jun 12 23:54 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so.3 -> libgrpc++.so.1.3.2
```

```
jeffmendoza@debian:~$ ls -l /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.*
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 1805448 Jun  8 22:18 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.a
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      18 Jun  8 22:18 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so -> libgrpc++.so.1.3.2
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      14 Jun  8 22:04 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so.1 -> libgrpc++.so.3
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  733240 Jun  8 22:18 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so.1.3.2
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      18 Jun  8 22:18 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so.3 -> libgrpc++.so.1.3.2
```
Having issue with Fedora, have to manually create symlinks for it to work

Edit: Got confused about which OS I was using. On OpenSuse 13.2 it built and ran the examples without issue.

Same issue when building on ~~OpenSuse 13.2~~ Scientific Linux 7.3 following the install from source instructions. 

I think this might be confusion between the version numbers of 'libgrpc' and 'libgrpc++' which are different, in my case: 
```
> ls -l /usr/local/lib
...
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root        16 Oct 20 08:25 libgrpc.so -> libgrpc.so.4.0.0
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root        18 Oct 20 08:37 libgrpc++.so -> libgrpc++.so.1.6.7
-rwxr-xr-x. 1 root root    336568 Oct 20 08:37 libgrpc++.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root        16 Oct 20 08:25 libgrpc.so.4 -> libgrpc.so.4.0.0
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root        18 Oct 20 08:37 libgrpc++.so.4 -> libgrpc++.so.1.6.7
-rwxr-xr-x. 1 root root   2283504 Oct 20 08:25 libgrpc.so.4.0.0
...
```
As you can see 'libgrpc' has a major version of 4 whereas 'libgrpc++' has major version of 1. 

In the (current) Makefile template [here](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/templates/Makefile.template#L1337) you have the following code:
```
  ifeq ($(SYSTEM),MINGW32)
  	$(Q) $(INSTALL) $(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG)/lib${lib.name}$(SHARED_VERSION_${lang_to_var[lib.language]})-dll.a $(prefix)/lib/lib${lib.name}.a
  else ifneq ($(SYSTEM),Darwin)
  	$(Q) ln -sf $(SHARED_PREFIX)${lib.name}$(SHARED_VERSION_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}).$(SHARED_EXT_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}) $(prefix)/lib/lib${lib.name}.so.${settings.core_version.major}
  	$(Q) ln -sf $(SHARED_PREFIX)${lib.name}$(SHARED_VERSION_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}).$(SHARED_EXT_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}) $(prefix)/lib/lib${lib.name}.so
  endif
```
which sets the shared library name using the variable `${settings.core_version.major}`. On my system this generates the following lines in the Makefile for the 'libgrpc++' soft link creation: 

```
ifeq ($(SYSTEM),MINGW32)
	$(Q) $(INSTALL) $(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG)/libgrpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP)-dll.a $(prefix)/lib/libgrpc++.a
else ifneq ($(SYSTEM),Darwin)
	$(Q) ln -sf $(SHARED_PREFIX)grpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP).$(SHARED_EXT_CPP) $(prefix)/lib/libgrpc++.so.4
	$(Q) ln -sf $(SHARED_PREFIX)grpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP).$(SHARED_EXT_CPP) $(prefix)/lib/libgrpc++.so
endif
```
which is wrong for the libgrpc++ library (should be 1 not 4)


Further on in the Makefile template, found [here](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/templates/Makefile.template#L1597), the code reads 
```
  ifeq ($(SYSTEM),Darwin)
  	$(Q) ${ld} ${ldflags} -L$(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG) -install_name $(SHARED_PREFIX)${lib.name}$(SHARED_VERSION_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}).$(SHARED_EXT_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}) -dynamiclib -o ${out_libbase}.$(SHARED_EXT_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}) ${common}${link_libs}
  else
  	$(Q) ${ld} ${ldflags} -L$(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG) -shared -Wl,-soname,lib${lib.name}.so.${settings.get(lang_to_var[lib.language].lower() + '_version').major} -o ${out_libbase}.$(SHARED_EXT_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}) ${common}${link_libs}
  	$(Q) ln -sf $(SHARED_PREFIX)${lib.name}$(SHARED_VERSION_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}).$(SHARED_EXT_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}) ${out_libbase}.so.${settings.get(lang_to_var[lib.language].lower() + '_version').major}
  	$(Q) ln -sf $(SHARED_PREFIX)${lib.name}$(SHARED_VERSION_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}).$(SHARED_EXT_${lang_to_var[lib.language]}) ${out_libbase}.so
  endif
```
This uses `${settings.get(lang_to_var[lib.language].lower() + '_version').major}` to obtain the major version.  On my system this generates the following lines for the 'libgrpc++' linking variables:
```
ifeq ($(SYSTEM),Darwin)
	$(Q) $(LDXX) $(LDFLAGS) -L$(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG) -install_name $(SHARED_PREFIX)grpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP).$(SHARED_EXT_CPP) -dynamiclib -o $(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG)/libgrpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP).$(SHARED_EXT_CPP) $(LIBGRPC++_OBJS) $(ZLIB_MERGE_LIBS) $(CARES_MERGE_LIBS) $(LDLIBSXX) $(LDLIBS_PROTOBUF) $(LDLIBS) -lgrpc -lgpr
else
	$(Q) $(LDXX) $(LDFLAGS) -L$(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG) -shared -Wl,-soname,libgrpc++.so.1 -o $(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG)/libgrpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP).$(SHARED_EXT_CPP) $(LIBGRPC++_OBJS) $(ZLIB_MERGE_LIBS) $(CARES_MERGE_LIBS) $(LDLIBSXX) $(LDLIBS_PROTOBUF) $(LDLIBS) -lgrpc -lgpr
	$(Q) ln -sf $(SHARED_PREFIX)grpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP).$(SHARED_EXT_CPP) $(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG)/libgrpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP).so.1
	$(Q) ln -sf $(SHARED_PREFIX)grpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP).$(SHARED_EXT_CPP) $(LIBDIR)/$(CONFIG)/libgrpc++$(SHARED_VERSION_CPP).so
endif
```
This tries to used the shared library that is referenced by the correctly named link `libgrpc++.so.1` (correct as in the major version number of the actual library is 1) but the actual link is the incorrectly named `libgrpc++.so.4`.

After rereading @jeffmendoza's comment I noticed that the debian build has the extra soft link `libgrpc++.so.1 -> libgrpc++.so.3` which makes the library lookup work and looks like a patch. So I checked my OpenSuse 13.2 build and found similar double indirections:
```
> ls -l /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++*
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  981912 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.a
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      18 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so -> libgrpc++.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      14 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so.1 -> libgrpc++.so.4
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  314112 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      18 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++.so.4 -> libgrpc++.so.1.6.7
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 4322516 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_cronet.a
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      25 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_cronet.so -> libgrpc++_cronet.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      21 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_cronet.so.1 -> libgrpc++_cronet.so.4
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 1001860 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_cronet.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      25 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_cronet.so.4 -> libgrpc++_cronet.so.1.6.7
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  280744 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_error_details.a
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      32 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_error_details.so -> libgrpc++_error_details.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      28 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_error_details.so.1 -> libgrpc++_error_details.so.4
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 1523388 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_error_details.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      32 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_error_details.so.4 -> libgrpc++_error_details.so.1.6.7
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  446224 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_reflection.a
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      29 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_reflection.so -> libgrpc++_reflection.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      25 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_reflection.so.1 -> libgrpc++_reflection.so.4
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 1728596 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_reflection.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      29 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_reflection.so.4 -> libgrpc++_reflection.so.1.6.7
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  871830 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_unsecure.a
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      27 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_unsecure.so -> libgrpc++_unsecure.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      23 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_unsecure.so.1 -> libgrpc++_unsecure.so.4
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  268852 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_unsecure.so.1.6.7
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root      27 Oct 19 10:14 /usr/local/lib/libgrpc++_unsecure.so.4 -> libgrpc++_unsecure.so.1.6.7
```
These extra links are missing from the Scientific Linux build hence why it fails to find the shared libraries. Though why those extra links are missing is a mystery; comparing the generated Makefile on the OpenSuse OS to that generated on the Scientific Linux OS gave no insight (`diff` of the two files resulted in null output, i.e. the files are the same).

Update 2017-10-24:
My issue was in my environment setup. Links were missing because the dynamic load library was not looking in `/usr/local/lib` for the shared libraries. I fixed this by appending `/usr/local/lib` to the `/etc/ld.so.conf` file.

Closing this based on the update on 10/24/2017
>>Update 2017-10-24:
My issue was in my environment setup. Links were missing because the dynamic load library was not looking in /usr/local/lib for the shared libraries. I fixed this by appending /usr/local/lib to the /etc/ld.so.conf file.
